hero.title: Swift to Hear
hero.subtitle: The body of Christ is called to speak the truth in love. But how can we speak in love if we have not first learned to listen?
hero.description: A Christadelphian community platform for practising the art of listening. Join us in recovering the spiritual discipline of attentive, compassionate listening through our three-part conversation practice.

james.text: Let every person be quick to hear, slow to speak, slow to anger.

proverbs18.text: If one gives an answer before he hears, it is his folly and shame.

corinthians.text: I could not address you as spiritual people, but as people of the flesh… For while there is jealousy and strife among you, are you not of the flesh?

timothy.text: The Lord's servant must not be quarrelsome but kind to everyone, able to teach, patiently enduring evil, correcting his opponents with gentleness.

ecclesiastes.text: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. To draw near to listen is better than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they are doing evil.

introduction.content: It is easy to forget how deeply the Scriptures value listening. In our culture—and often in our ecclesial conversations—there is a quiet pressure to be the one who knows, who teaches, who speaks with confidence. But Scripture pushes us toward a different kind of wisdom: not the quick retort or the flawless argument, but the attentive ear.

listeningDeficit.title: A listening deficit
listeningDeficit.content1: The Proverbs warn of the folly of answering before listening. James reminds us that hearing must come before speaking, and that anger—often the fruit of defensive or unchecked speech—does not produce the righteousness of God. Paul, writing to Corinth, describes a church fractured by immaturity—strife, factions, jealousy—and marks these as symptoms of people still driven by the flesh rather than the Spirit.
listeningDeficit.content2: It is not difficult to see parallels in our own community. We are bound together in the hope of the Kingdom and in a shared love for Scripture. But we also know the pain of fractured conversations—whether over doctrine, relationships, or ecclesial practice—where we speak past one another or fail to fully see one another.

practising.title: Practising the art of listening
practising.intro1: If we are to become mature in Christ, we must recover the art of listening—not passive silence, but active, compassionate attention. The kind of listening that Jesus often invited through his poetic and enigmatic statements. His parables, questions, and open-ended encounters called others to listen more deeply—to themselves, to him, and to the movement of God in their lives. This kind of listening slows us down, draws us out, and opens a space where the Wisdom might speak.
practising.intro2: To that end, a small group of us are beginning to experiment with a simple practice designed to help us listen better and trust more deeply in the process of godly conversation. It centres around three roles:

speaker.title: Speaker
speaker.description: One who shares from Scripture, experience, or conviction.

listener.title: Listener
listener.description: One who attends fully, without rebuttal or reaction, offering back what they have heard.

scribe.title: Scribe
scribe.description: One who records the unfolding insights and themes.

practising.rotation: Crucially, these roles rotate. Everyone becomes a speaker, a listener, and a scribe after an allotted time. No one controls the outcome. Instead, we place faith in what can emerge when we listen together in love. As Proverbs 20:5 says, "The purposes of a person's heart are deep waters, but one who has insight draws them out." This practice is a way of drawing out—not just others' words, but the meaning beneath them, even those meanings hidden from ourselves.
practising.discovery: As the conversation unfolds, it often leads us to discoveries none of us could have reached alone. As Paul reminds us in 1 Corinthians 13:12, "For now we see through a glass, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I am known." Our understanding is always partial. But through mutual listening, we begin to uncover not only what we don't know, but what we don't know we don't know—the blind spots and assumptions that only another's voice can help illuminate.
practising.faith: This practice is not about asserting control over words or ideas, but about cultivating faith in the conversation itself—faith that when we "submit to one another out of reverence for Christ" (Ephesians 5:21), something deeper than individual insight can emerge. We begin, as 2 Timothy 2:24–25 teaches, to "patiently endure," "correct with gentleness," and leave room for "God [to] perhaps grant them repentance leading to a knowledge of the truth."

format.title: Why Use This Format?
format.intro1: The specific structure—Speaker, Listener, Scribe—has no direct precedent in Scripture, it is a newer technology. But many of our current practices are. The early church had no hymn books, Sunday schools, or digital tools. We use these because they help us live out the principles of Scripture.
format.intro2: This listening format is just that—a tool to enact timeless values:

humility.title: Humility
humility.verse: Do nothing from selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility count others more significant than yourselves.

mutualSubmission.title: Mutual Submission
mutualSubmission.verse: Submitting to one another out of reverence for Christ.

attentiveListening.title: Attentive Listening
attentiveListening.verse: Let every person be quick to hear, slow to speak, slow to anger.

drawingWisdom.title: Drawing Out Wisdom
drawingWisdom.verse: The purposes of a person's heart are deep waters, but one who has insight draws them out.

pitfalls.title: It also helps us guard against common pitfalls:

items.reactiveness: Reactiveness and debate: The Listener doesn't reply, but reflects back what they heard.
items.dominance: Dominance and status: The roles rotate—no one stays in charge.
items.losingInsight: Losing insight: The Scribe helps capture what might otherwise be forgotten or overlooked.

format.grounding: This structure is a modern method, but by testing its spirit—discerning whether it aligns with godly wisdom—we find it grounded in Scripture. We are not seeking novelty for its own sake, but new ways to become what we are called to be: a people shaped by love, wisdom, and deep mutual care.
format.discernment: Some may worry that careful listening opens us to harmful or misleading ideas. But to listen is not to agree. Adam's mistake was not listening to Eve—it was obeying against God's command. Throughout Scripture, God's people are called to discern, not dismiss; to test the spirit of what is said, not to fear hearing it. Listening creates the space for such discernment. Inquiry helps us hear more exactly what is being said—so often we react not to what was truly spoken, but to a misunderstanding. The practice of attentive listening slows us down and gives space for clarification, preventing unnecessary conflict and helping the body grow in truth and love.

rootedInWord.title: Rooted in the Word
rootedInWord.content: We are grounding this approach in Scripture. We believe listening is not just a communication skill; it's a spiritual practice. It aligns with the gentleness and patience Paul urged in 2 Timothy. It creates the conditions where we may correct without quarrelling, and teach without pride. It is the soil in which love, patience, and mutual forbearance can grow.

speaker.title: Speaker Practice Exercise
speaker.instruction: Take 30 seconds to practice speaking from your heart without planning.
speaker.prompt: Complete this sentence: "Right now, what feels most alive in me is..."
speaker.guidance: Notice any impulse to edit or perfect your words. Just let whatever wants to emerge come through.

listener.title: Listener Practice Exercise
listener.instruction: Practice reflecting back what you hear without adding your own interpretation.
listener.prompt: Listen to this sample and reflect back the essence of what you heard.
listener.guidance: Focus on what you actually heard rather than what you think about it. Start with "What I heard was..." or "It sounds like..."

scribe.title: Scribe Practice Exercise
scribe.instruction: Practice capturing key insights and themes without trying to record everything.
scribe.prompt: Listen to this sample conversation and note the main themes that emerge.
scribe.guidance: Look for patterns, emotions, and core insights rather than transcribing word-for-word.

observer.title: Observer Practice Exercise
observer.instruction: Practice witnessing group dynamics and communication patterns.
observer.prompt: Watch this sample interaction and notice the quality of listening and speaking.
observer.guidance: Pay attention to pace, presence, and how the roles support each other.
